narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a whole bunch about the chart and influence of religion in America since before the country's inception to the War on Terror. It's both remarkable and horrifying and every week I came away with a greater understanding and even greater questions about America's involvement and responsibility, if you can call it that, to the rest of the world.

Good overview of US military history and theologic roots. The class is structured chronologically so you begin in the colonial era and end in the 21st century, which I thought was a great way to organize the course. Genuinely gave me a different perspective on foreign policy.
I learned a lot about time management, especially with the longer final essay. I also developed an understanding of American history that I had never had before.
pulling meaning from a lot of reading

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very strong overall--we read trxts that kept us informed and offered interesting and new perspectives. The only critique I could add were that there were very minimal non-white/non-male authors in what we read, and those we BIPOC and/or non-male authors we did read often felt glanced over or barely discussed in class.

Can't really identify any weaknesses -- this was a great course. My personal preference would be more class time devoted to the 21st century, but again thats just a personal preference. The strength of the course is definitely Professor Stout, even via zoom he made the seminar very engaging and not nearly as painful as some of my other remote classes.

Strengths: Interesting and unique course topic, great professor that was intimately familiar with the material, 

Weaknesses: I am surprised that this class did not grant a writing credit considering there were 30 pages of graded writing. I have no real complaints with this class, though.

The syllabus and reading assignments were well planned and thought out. We covered so much material while still being able to go to great depths. I wish we had been able to spend less time talking about the general history of each American war studied during seminar and more time on primary source documents or looking at certain case studies. I think this could be achieved through assigning a general YouTube video on the history of a given war each week so as to also avoid not assigning more reading.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the size of the class was perfect (around six students). I also thought the weekly reading responses were a good way of bringing everyone in to the conversation. I really appreciated the break during every class to get away from zoom for a moment.

I feel like this course was as good as it could have been considering the circumstances. It was heavily discussion-based which is always difficult in a zoom call, but I feel like there aren't many ways to improve that experience.
having small group really helped with meaningful discussion

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very much yes, I had a great time and the whole class had great things to offer

Absolutely. Even as a senior I filled in vital gaps in my knowledge of American history. I especially would recommend this course to students with little or no background in American military or Christian history. One of the most engaging seminars I have taken at Yale (even via zoom). Very reasonable workload.

I would recommend this course to another student. I am mostly a STEM person, but I decided to take this class to explore some other subjects. I really enjoyed it and I thought the topics were interesting. It was a lot of reading per week, but I would still recommend it.

Yes! Prof. Stout is incredibly knowledgeable on this topic and obviously loves discussing it with students. It was truly an honor to go to seminar even over Zoom and both learn from and try out new ideas and arguments with him and my peers.
yes, but mostly because the content was niche, and my niche, so I'd recommend it to people who want to learn a lot about this topic
